_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Chlorine is the most commonly used substance for disinfecting drinking water.  The addition of chlorine or chlorine compounds to water is called chlorination.  Chlorination is considered to be the most important process for preventing the spread of waterborne disease in drinking water.  The Los Angeles Department of Water and Power (LADWP) also uses chlorine for drinking water disinfection purposes at the Upper Stone Canyon Station to protect public health per state and federal water quality standards.  Storing and handling large quantities of chlorine can create hazardous situations. The LADWP takes safety obligations in storing and using chlorine as seriously as it takes in providing safe drinking water.



The LADWP Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station (USCCS) chlorine handling process is subject to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program and Plan, and also to the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program regulations. The facilities subject to the EPA and CalARP Program regulations are required to prepare and update Risk Management Plans (RMPs). The RMP is to include policies and procedures followed to safely operate the facility and the actions taken by the facility in an event of an emergency.



The LADWP prepared and submitted RMPs for the USCCS in 1999, 2004 and 2008. The LADWP prepared Program Level 2 RMPs from 1999 through 2008 because Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station is not subject to PSM regulations. However, in the excess of caution, LADWP prepared a Program Level 3 RMP in 2010. The 2014 update of the 2010 RMP also demonstrated compliance with the Program Level 3 requirements. This document is an update of the June 2014 RMP for the Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station. 



The following information is specifically required in the RMP Executive Summary:



?    Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.

?    General facility and regulated substances information.

?    Offsite consequ

ence analysis results.

?    Summary of the accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps.

?    Five-year accident history summary.

?    Emergency response program summary.

?    Planned changes to improve safety.



The above information for the Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station is provided below.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



The LADWP accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates the use of proven technology, trains staff in operation and maintenance practices, and uses tested and proven management system practices. All applicable requirements of the State of California and EPA's Prevention Program are adhered to, including key elements such as training, systems management, and emergency response procedures.  



The LADWP emergency response policy involves the preparation of emergency response plans for hazardous materials which are tailored to each facility and to the emergency response services available in the community, and is in compliance with the EPA and CalARP Program Emergency Response Program Requirements.  The LADWP has prepared an Emergency Response Plan for the Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station to facilitate coordination and emergency planning with offsite response officials and facilities in the event of an emergency. The Emergency Response Plan has been coordinated with the local response agency (City of Los Angeles Fire Department). The Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station has good record in preventing accidents from happening.



General Facility and Regulated Substance Information



The Upper Stone Canyon Station is located at 1900 North Stone Canyon Road in Los Angeles, California. There are multiple chlorine feed points on the reservoir complex property to disinfect water in Upper and Lower Stone Canyon Reservoirs, the Upper Stone Canyon bypass pipelines #1 and #2, and the membrane filtration plant. The treated water is piped into the

distribution network, which serves parts of west Los Angeles with potable water. The station building consists of a chlorine storage room, chlorine equipment room, an electrical equipment room, several chemical storage rooms, and a 4,700-lb capacity dry media scrubber room. The facility stores chlorine, a regulated toxic substance under the EPA and CalARP Program rules. The Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station stores a maximum of 22 ton chlorine containers. Ten of these ton containers can be connected to the chlorination process to feed chlorine liquid or gas.  The maximum quantity of chlorine present at the Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station at any given time exceeds the listed threshold quantities in the EPA and CalARP regulations. It also exceeds the listed threshold quantities in the federal and California Occupational Safety and Health Administration PSM Standards. However, the facility is normally unoccupied and water treatment operators visit the facility daily and respond to any trouble alarms that may occur. Therefore, the LADWP Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station is not subject to federal or California OSHA PSM standards.



The design incorporates two banks of four ton containers each, which normally feed liquid chlorine to evaporators. There is an automatic switchover system that determines which liquid chlorine header feeds the evaporators. This system consists of a control panel, two motorized ball valves, and a pressure switch on the liquid header before the evaporators. When the pressure in the liquid chlorine supply line drops to 20 psi, the switchover system opens the valve isolating the standby bank of ton containers to allow liquid chlorine to flow. At the same time, it closes the ball valve on the now empty bank of ton containers.



The system is also configured with gas headers for each of the two banks of four ton containers. This is essentially a complete gas feed system with automatic switchover capability. It can be used durin

g periods of low chlorine demand, or if the liquid system is out of service for repairs. It has been provided because of the uncertainty of operations at this site in the future.



Because the normal operation is by withdrawing liquid chlorine, and the evaporators are equipped with motorized vacuum regulating valves downstream, it is possible for the gas supply to the chlorinators to be automatically shut off at the vacuum-regulating valve. These valves can close upon a low temperature condition in the evaporator or at the valve, or upon power failure. For this reason, in order to assure no interruptions of chlorine feed, a third bank of two ton containers is provided. These two ton containers connect to a gas header which leads to three automatic switchover type vacuum regulating valves in parallel acting as an automatic backup gas supply. The vacuum regulating valves have a capacity of 3,000 ppd each, for a total feed capacity of 9,000 ppd. The valves open automatically based on a high vacuum condition that pulls the valve out of its detent position. Because this is a mechanical setting on each separate valve, and the settings are not exactly the same, it is likely that not all of the valves will open at once. One would open, followed by a second and then a third if the feed demand is great enough. With only two one-ton containers supplying this gas manifold, the sustainable gas feed rate is only about 800 ppd due to the inherent physical properties of chlorine.  Therefore, when it comes on line it must be considered an emergency supply only.  A quick response from an operator is needed to come to the station and either get the liquid system back on line, or else start shedding chlorine feed (such as shore feeds) to a rate that can be sustained from two gas containers.  Other options include placing one or both of the primary banks of four one-ton containers each on their gas header systems.  This emergency backup is intended for only an hour or so of feed before

intervention.



The gaseous chlorine from the evaporators or from the chlorine gas header proceeds to the chlorinators that regulate the flow of chlorine.  Chlorine gas from the vacuum regulating valve with check-relief units is pulled by vacuum to the chlorinators and then to the injectors. It is important to note that in case of loss of vacuum downstream of the vacuum regulating valve with check-relief units, air would be drawn in rather than chlorine gas being released. In addition, the vacuum regulating valve with check-relief unit will shut down the chlorine supply to the chlorinator, operating as a shut-off valve. 



A dry media type chlorine gas scrubber system (main scrubber) is installed at the station. The unit is actuated by chlorine detectors at a chlorine concentration of 3 ppm.  The scrubber can neutralize up to 4,700 lbs of chlorine in case of a chlorine leak. The scrubber draws suction from the chlorine ton container and chlorinator rooms through a duct.  The station is equipped with an uninterruptible power supply (UPS) in addition to a backup power generator. Therefore, in case of the failure of regular power, the scrubber will remain functional.



A dry media chlorine "mini-scrubber" unit (MS) has also been installed at the Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station. The MS is an emergency chlorine scrubber intended to protect personnel working in the building or immediate area from a chlorine gas release from the pressure safety relief vent provided in the vacuum regulator check units. Mini-scrubber can neutralize up to 25 lbs of chlorine, and the media manufacturer specifies chlorine removal to less than 5 parts per billion.



All the ton containers connected to the process are equipped with Halogen actuators which shut the ton container valves when desired.  These actuators close all eight ton containers (two banks of four each) that are connected to either the liquid or gas headers when any of the chlorine gas sensors in the chlorine contain

er or chlorinator rooms detect gas exceeding 10 ppm.  



The chlorinators supply gaseous chlorine to each of the Upper Reservoir, the two bypass lines, the Lower Reservoir, and the membrane filtration plant injection systems.  Chlorine gas is withdrawn from the chlorinators under vacuum to the injectors.  In the injectors, chlorine mixes with a high-pressure water supply to form a concentrated solution.  The chlorine solution discharged from the injector is diffused into the pipelines or the reservoirs through multiple diffuser nozzles.  The Stone Canyon Complex injection system has eighteen injectors spread out among seven vaults, at various locations throughout the complex.



Seven chlorine leak sensors are provided in the station to detect chlorine leaks.  The sensors are located in the chlorine container and chlorinator rooms, as well as from the scrubber inlet and outlet ducts.  The detectors signal an alarm by activating a flashing red light over the entry door to the building, as well as an audible alarm within the container and chlorination rooms, and activating an alarm at the Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant (LAAFP) Control Room at Sylmar.  Also, the chlorine injector vaults are equipped with chlorine leak sensors.



Process control is by a programmable controller, which determines the feed rate based on the water flow rate and the chlorine residual.  There are flow meters transmitting flow signals to the controller.  Chlorine residual analyzers continuously monitor the treated water residuals.



In the event power is lost at the chlorine facilities, an alarm will alert the LAAFP control room.  Chlorine flow will continue unaffected, with no safety consequences. An emergency generator will automatically start and supply power to the entire system.



The facility is normally unoccupied; water treatment operators visit the facility daily. A response team coordinated from LADWP Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant (LAAFP) responds to any trouble al

arms, which may occur. Access to the facility is through gates, which are kept locked all the time.



Summary of the Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



The LADWP accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:



?    Detailed management system and clear levels of responsibilities and team member roles.

?    Comprehensive process safety information that is readily available to staff, emergency responders, and contractors.

?    Comprehensive preventive maintenance program.

?    Performance of process hazard analysis of equipment and procedures with operation and maintenance staff participation and review.

?    State-of-the-art process and safety equipment.

?    Accurate and effective operating procedures, written with the participation of the station operators.

?    High level training for the operators and maintenance staff.

?    A State of California Water Treatment Facility Staff Certification is required to operate the station.

?    An incident investigation, inspection, and auditing program using qualified staff.



Chemical-specific prevention steps for the chlorination system include the following: availability of self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA), worn by the operators during connection/disconnection of chlorine supply; awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of chlorine; presence of chlorine detectors with remote monitoring; the use of Halogen actuators on the ton containers; a chlorine main scrubber; and a chlorine mini-scrubber.



Process and Chemical Safety Information



Comprehensive chemical data has been assembled to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds, health hazard, and chemical exposure limitations, as well as detailed physical properties of chlorine.  This information includes chlorine background information and Safety Data Sheets.



Equipment safety information was compiled on the chlorination process. Specifications for the chlorination process are collecte

d and provided in one place for easy reference. Details (such as maximum intended inventory; safe upper and lower temperatures; and safe upper and lower pressures for the chlorination facility) are on file at the facility.  The LADWP also has procedures in place that are triggered to update process safety information if there is a major change that makes existing information inaccurate.



Process Hazard Analysis



In 1996, a detailed hazard review/Process Hazard Analysis was conducted for the equipment and procedures.  The hazard review/PHA was revalidated in April 1999. In March 2004, a hazard review/PHA was again performed for the whole chlorination station. A hazard review/PHA for modifications to the facility was performed (based on the design drawings) in March 2002. This hazard review/PHA was further reviewed in August 2008 after the facility was constructed. The 2008 hazard review/PHA was again reviewed in June 2013 as part of the five year update of the hazard review/PHA. The 2013 PHA was again reviewed and updated in April 2014. A PHA was again performed for the USCCS on March 15, 2019, and will be updated again within a five-year period or whenever there will be a major change in the process. A list of recommended actions was developed in March 2019 to further improve the chlorine safety. All of these recommendations are being evaluated for implementation. The LADWP staff will document the completion of the recommended actions.



A seismic assessment, including the walkthrough on February 13, 2019 was completed for the chlorination station in April 2019. A set of recommended actions was developed in April 2019 to further improve the safety of the chlorination station. All of these recommendations are being evaluated for implementation. The LADWP staff will document the completion of the recommended actions. The seismic assessment was performed following the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) Region 1 guidance document.



Operating Procedures

The LADWP has prepared written operating procedures for Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station that provide clear instructions or steps for safely conducting activities relating to chlorination process. They are consistent with the chlorine safety information. Written operating procedures included in the facility's Operation and Maintenance (O&M) Manual is as follows:



?    Delivery of Chlorine.

?    Ton Container Connections.

?    Initial Startup Procedure.

?    Normal Operation.

?    Normal Shutdown.

?    Temporary Operations.

?    Emergency Operations.

?    Emergency Shutdown.

?    Startup Following Emergency Shutdown.



Training 



The LADWP ensures that each employee operating or maintaining the chlorination process, and each employee newly assigned to these processes, is trained and tested for competency in the operating procedures listed above.  The LADWP employee training documentation files include training records for each employee assigned to operate or maintain the chlorination process. The training ensures that the employee has the required knowledge, skills, and abilities to safely perform the duties and responsibilities, including chlorine emergency response, as provided in the operating procedures.  Employee training includes, as a minimum, the following elements:



?    Safety Information.

?    Process Technology and Process Equipment, including safety systems.

?    Maintenance Procedures.

?    Operating Procedures for the chlorine system.

?    RMP Program contents.

?    Emergency Response Plan and Procedures.



Refresher training is provided at least every three years to each employee operating the chlorination process to ensure that the employee understands and adheres to the current operating procedures.  In addition, the LADWP ensures that operators are trained in any updated or new procedures before startup of a process after major modifications. 



Contractors 



The LADWP contractors' procedures specify the information required to be provided to the contractors per

forming work on or near the chlorination process, the training requirements for contractor employees, and mechanism to obtain assurance from contractors that they have informed their employees of the appropriate safety rules. The LADWP provides information and explanations concerning the hazards and processes. 



Pre-Startup Safety Review and Mechanical Integrity Program 



The LADWP has procedures in place to ensure that a pre-startup safety review is conducted prior to starting a new covered process or prior to making modifications to the chlorination system that require a Management of Change (MOC) procedure implementation. The required conditions prior to startup include the following:



?    Construction and/or equipment are in accordance with design specifications.

?    Safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate.

?    A PHA has been performed for new facilities and recommendations have been resolved or implemented before startup.

?    At modified facilities, MOC requirements have been met.

?    Training of each operating and maintenance employee involved in the process is complete.



These procedures ensure that no new and/or significantly modified process will startup and no regulated substances will be introduced into such a process before the pre-startup safety review. This constitutes a final check that the process and equipment are ready to go and that the recommendations of the PHA have been implemented or adequately addressed. This will ensure that the design and construction of a new or modified process is safely executed and that the facility is prepared to operate it. 



Mechanical integrity procedures for the plant ensure that written maintenance procedures are implemented and documented, including training of maintenance personnel.



Maintenance 



The LADWP operates a maintenance program, MAXIMO Program that generates a work order for performing the preventive maintenance routine, which occurs after a design

ated time past the closing of the previous work order for that particular maintenance process.  Description of the work to be performed is included with the printed work order. The water treatment supervisors are responsible for the maintenance of the chlorination system.  



In addition, the written maintenance procedure is provided in the O&M Manual as follows: Preventive maintenance schedules are provided which summarize inspection, test, and maintenance schedules on a daily, weekly, bi-monthly, monthly, biannual, and annual, every 2 to 10 years, and on as-needed basis.  These procedures allow the operator to rapidly review what maintenance is necessary.  The schedules are supplemental to the log sheets onsite and provide a summary and quick reference to manufacturer's O&M manuals.  A maintenance log book is provided onsite for Operator quick reference.



The LADWP documents inspection, testing, and maintenance of chlorination equipment and assures the performance is performed in accordance with the recommendations of the manufacturer and industry groups.



Hot Work Permits and Management of Change 



Hot work refers to work involving electric or gas welding, cutting, brazing, or similar flame or spark producing operations. The hot work procedures require the issuance of a hot work permit whenever it is conducted on or near the chlorination process and other areas deemed appropriate as described in these procedures.  Fire prevention and protection systems are in place before a hot work permit is issued. The permit indicates the dates the work is authorized for, the location, and specific operational requirements, and it is kept on file in the administrative office. 



The LADWP Management of Change procedures include steps required to be taken by plant personnel before implementing changes to chlorination equipment, procedures, raw materials, and processing conditions. Training, process safety information, operating procedures, and maintenance procedures are

updated according to the changes made.



Internal Compliance Audits 



The LADWP has been certifying every three years (or earlier) that compliance with Program 2 Prevention Program requirements for the chlorination station is met and that procedures and practices developed are adequate and being followed. Starting March 2010, the LADWP certified compliance with Program 3 Prevention Program requirements. The two most recent audit reports and a list of the recommendations are retained in the LADWP's files.



The compliance audit consists of separating the RMP program elements or sections, and auditing each element to determine compliance and effectiveness. For each internal audit, the audit team completes a Compliance Audit Certification Page and a Compliance Audit Checklist. The Compliance Audit Certification Page provides process identification, the dates of the audit, team members, and certification by the audit leader.  The Compliance Audit Checklist details the requirements of each RMP element and contains questions that may assist with the auditing process. The audit checklist for each element consists of the following three sections:



?    Records Review: A review of the RMP written Prevention Program.

?    Onsite Conditions: The audit team reviews the program elements based on observation of the plant conditions and safety practices.

?    Interviews:  The program elements are evaluated by interviewing personnel from appropriate functions including operations, maintenance, management, and contractors.



Team members record RMP program deficiencies identified during the audit on the checklist.



Incident Investigation 



The LADWP incident investigation procedures describe incident reporting, investigation, and investigation reporting steps to be followed by plant personnel. The incident investigation is started promptly but no later than 48 hours after the event. The LADWP promptly addresses and resolves all recommendations and implements the recommendations

in a timely manner to prevent an incident recurrence. All incident investigation reports are retained in the LADWP's file for at least a period of five years from the date the reports are completed.



Five-year Accident History Summary



No chlorine release that could have caused safety or health hazard (deaths, injuries, property or environmental damage evacuations, or sheltering in place) occurred at the Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station during the last five years.



Emergency Response Program Summary



The LADWP is a first responder, its employees respond to chlorine accidental release.  In the event an accidental release that could result in offsite consequences occurs, external resources, such as the City of Los Angeles Fire Department will also be solicited to respond.  



As part of the emergency response program, the LADWP has developed and implemented an emergency response plan for the purpose of protecting public health and the environment. The following elements are included:



(a)    An emergency response plan, maintained at the Upper Stone Canyon Chlorination Station  and at the Los Angeles Aqueduct Filtration Plant (LAAFP) containing:



?    Organizational structure (chain-of-command) and responsibilities of various LADWP personnel.

?    Procedures for planning and coordination with off-site emergency response organizations.

?    Details of the training programs for all employees involved with the chlorination process, contractor training, and medical surveillance of LADWP personnel who respond to chlorine releases.

?    Details of emergency recognition and prevention at the LADWP.

?    Procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies about accidental releases.

?    Documentation of proper first aid and emergency medical treatment necessary to treat accidental human exposures and the detailed information on emergency health care.

?    Procedures and measures for emergency response after an accidental release.



(b)    Procedures for

the use of emergency response equipment and for its inspection, testing, and maintenance. 

(c)    Training in relevant procedures for all employees involved with the chlorination process.

(d)    Procedures to review and update, as appropriate, the emergency response plan to reflect changes and ensure that employees are informed of changes.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety 



Based on the April 2014 PHA performed for the chlorination system, four recommendations were made. All of these recommendations have been evaluated. Additionally, nine recommendations to further improve chlorine safety were identified in March 2019, when PHA was again performed for the USCCS.



Based on the February 2014 seismic assessment, four recommendations were made for the USCCS. All the above recommendations have been evaluated and implemented by the LADWP. Additionally, three recommendations to further improve chlorine safety were identified in April 2019, when seismic assessment was again performed for the USCCS.



It is expected that all the above 2019 recommendations will be evaluated and implemented by September 2021. The implementation of these recommendations will further improve the safety of the chlorination system.
